title: TRESA Compliance Requirements
content: All real estate professionals must comply with TRESA requirements including mandatory representation agreements, disclosure obligations, and professional conduct standards. Non-compliance may result in disciplinary action.

title: Buyer Representation Agreement Rules
content: Real estate professionals must have a signed buyer representation agreement before showing properties. The agreement must clearly outline commission arrangements, duties, and term of representation.

title: Disclosure Obligations
content: Real estate professionals must disclose all material facts, conflicts of interest, and commission arrangements. Failure to disclose may result in penalties and legal liability.

title: Professional Conduct Standards
content: TRESA establishes higher professional conduct standards including continuing education requirements, ethical obligations, and client service standards.

title: Complaint and Discipline Process
content: RECO investigates complaints against real estate professionals. The process includes investigation, mediation, and disciplinary hearings with potential penalties including fines and license suspension.

title: Consumer Protection Measures
content: TRESA includes enhanced consumer protection measures such as mandatory written agreements, clear disclosure requirements, and improved complaint resolution processes.

title: Commission Disclosure Rules
content: All commission arrangements must be clearly disclosed in writing. Real estate professionals must explain how commissions are calculated and paid in buyer representation agreements.

title: Licensing and Registration
content: All real estate professionals must be licensed and registered under TRESA. Licensing requirements include education, examination, and ongoing professional development.

title: Record Keeping Requirements
content: Real estate professionals must maintain detailed records of all transactions, agreements, and client communications as required under TRESA regulations.

title: Penalties and Enforcement
content: TRESA violations can result in administrative penalties, fines up to $50,000 for individuals and $100,000 for corporations, license suspension or revocation, and criminal charges for serious offenses.

title: Administrative Penalties Framework
content: Administrative penalties up to $25,000 can be imposed for TRESA violations without requiring a criminal conviction. These penalties promote compliance and prevent economic benefit from violations. Payment prevents criminal charges for the same violation.

title: Lien and Collection Powers
content: If fines or administrative penalties remain unpaid for 60+ days, the director can create liens against personal and real property, report to credit agencies, and enforce collection through court orders.

title: Insurance and Financial Security
content: TRESA requires brokerages, brokers, and salespersons to maintain prescribed insurance coverage, bonds, or collateral security. This may include mandatory participation in group insurance programs.

title: Trust Account Management
content: Brokerages must maintain trust accounts in compliance with prescribed rules. Regulations govern account management, record keeping, and procedures for winding down accounts when registration ends.

title: Multiple Representation Rules
content: TRESA governs when real estate professionals can represent multiple parties in a transaction. Specific disclosure requirements and prohibited circumstances are prescribed by regulation.

title: Specialization Certification
content: Real estate professionals can obtain specialist certifications in prescribed areas. Requirements include specialized education, testing, and ongoing maintenance of certification standards.

title: Information Disclosure to Registrar
content: Registrants must provide requested information to the registrar about trades, business operations, and interested parties. Information must be provided in prescribed forms and verified by affidavit when required.

title: Confidentiality and Information Protection
content: Information obtained in administering TRESA must be kept confidential except for legal proceedings, administration purposes, consumer protection, or law enforcement activities.

title: Service of Legal Documents
content: Legal notices and orders under TRESA can be served personally, by registered mail, or other provable methods. Registered mail service is deemed effective on the third day after mailing.

title: Appeals and Hearing Rights
content: Administrative penalty orders can be appealed within 15 days. The appeal body conducts hearings and can confirm, revoke, or vary penalties. Appeals don't automatically stay enforcement.

title: Registration Conditions and Requirements
content: TRESA registration includes prescribed conditions, education requirements, and ongoing compliance obligations. Violations can result in additional conditions, suspension, or revocation.

title: Quality Assurance Programs
content: The director and administrative authority can conduct quality assurance programs to monitor compliance and use collected information to improve administration and enforcement.

title: Electronic Commerce Compliance
content: TRESA regulations govern how electronic commerce laws apply to real estate transactions, ensuring digital processes meet legal requirements for contracts and disclosures.

title: Exemptions and Special Circumstances
content: Regulations may exempt certain persons or classes of trades from TRESA requirements with prescribed conditions. Exemptions are granted based on specific criteria and public interest considerations.

title: Electronic Commerce Compliance
content: TRESA regulations govern how electronic commerce laws apply to real estate transactions, ensuring digital processes meet legal requirements for contracts and disclosures.

title: Transitional Provisions
content: TRESA includes provisions for transitioning from previous legislation, handling existing registrations, and ensuring continuity during regulatory changes and implementation.

title: Administrative Authority Powers
content: The administrative authority designated under TRESA has broad powers to oversee compliance, conduct investigations, impose penalties, and ensure professional standards are maintained across the real estate industry.

title: Material Facts Disclosure Requirements
content: Real estate professionals must disclose all material facts that would reasonably be expected to affect property value, desirability, or influence transaction decisions. Failure to disclose material facts can result in significant penalties.

title: Brokerage Supervision and Management
content: Brokerages must ensure proper supervision of all registrants, maintain oversight of business operations, and implement compliance systems to prevent violations and protect consumers.

title: Personal Real Estate Corporation Rules
content: Qualified real estate professionals may incorporate through personal real estate corporations that meet prescribed criteria, while maintaining all professional obligations and liability requirements under TRESA.

title: Conflict of Interest Management
content: Registrants must identify, disclose, and manage conflicts of interest, including holdings in other brokerages, personal interests in transactions, and any circumstances that could compromise professional judgment.

title: Consumer Protection Framework
content: TRESA establishes comprehensive consumer protection measures including mandatory written agreements, enhanced disclosure requirements, professional conduct standards, and improved complaint resolution processes.

title: Professional Conduct Standards and Ethics
content: All registrants must adhere to prescribed professional conduct standards, ethical obligations, and client service requirements. Violations can result in disciplinary action, education requirements, or registration suspension.

title: Quality Assurance and Monitoring Programs
content: The director and administrative authority conduct quality assurance programs to monitor industry compliance, assess practices, and use findings to improve administration and enforcement of TRESA requirements.

title: Registration Conditions and Ongoing Requirements
content: TRESA registration includes prescribed conditions, education requirements, and ongoing compliance obligations. Additional conditions may be imposed based on circumstances, violations, or regulatory needs.

title: Information Gathering and Reporting Powers
content: The registrar has broad authority to request information from registrants about trades, business operations, and interested parties. Information must be provided in prescribed forms and verified when required.

title: Exemptions and Special Circumstances
content: Regulations may provide exemptions for certain persons or trade types based on specific criteria and public interest considerations, with prescribed conditions and limitations.

title: Document Service and Legal Procedures
content: Legal notices and orders under TRESA can be served through various methods including personal service, registered mail, or other provable delivery methods, with specific timing requirements for effectiveness.

title: Fee Structure and Revenue Framework
content: The Minister establishes fees for registration, renewal, examinations, and administrative services. Fee revenue supports TRESA administration, enforcement activities, and consumer protection programs.

title: Public Information and Transparency Requirements
content: The registrar maintains public records of registrant names, registration status, and prescribed information to ensure transparency and enable consumer verification of professional credentials.

title: Trust Account Security and Protection
content: Trust accounts must be maintained with prescribed security measures, proper segregation of client funds, appropriate record-keeping, and procedures to protect client money from misuse or loss.

title: Continuing Education and Professional Development
content: Registrants must complete ongoing education requirements from designated organizations to maintain competency, stay current with industry changes, and fulfill professional development obligations.

title: Electronic Transaction Validation
content: TRESA ensures electronic real estate transactions meet legal requirements for contract formation, signature validity, document integrity, and compliance with electronic commerce legislation.

title: Industry Standards and Best Practices
content: TRESA establishes minimum standards for real estate practice while encouraging adoption of best practices in client service, transaction management, and professional conduct throughout the industry.

title: Real Estate Definition and Scope
content: TRESA defines real estate broadly to include leasehold interests, businesses with or without premises, fixtures, stock-in-trade, and goods connected with business operations. Regulations may prescribe specific exclusions.

title: Associated Persons and Business Relationships
content: TRESA defines associated persons including corporate officers/directors, partnership members, and persons with beneficial interests or control over business operations. These relationships affect registration eligibility and compliance obligations.

title: Brokerage Registration and Structure
content: Brokerages must be registered as corporations, partnerships, sole proprietorships, or other legal entities. Each brokerage requires a designated broker of record and must maintain proper business premises and supervision structures.

title: Multiple Office Registration Requirements
content: Brokerages operating from multiple locations must register each office separately. One office must be designated as the main office, with proper supervision and management structures for all branch offices.

title: Trust Account Regulations and Requirements
content: Brokerages must maintain trust accounts in approved financial institutions, properly segregate client funds, maintain detailed records, and follow prescribed procedures for handling and disbursing trust monies.

title: Unclaimed Trust Money Procedures
content: If trust money remains unclaimed for specified periods, brokerages must follow prescribed procedures including reasonable efforts to locate rightful owners before transferring funds to regulatory authorities.

title: Financial Responsibility and Interested Persons
content: Registrants must demonstrate financial responsibility and disclose relationships with interested persons who may have beneficial interests, control, or financial involvement in their business operations.

title: Registration Refusal and Appeal Rights
content: The registrar may refuse registration applications that don't meet prescribed requirements. Applicants have appeal rights to the Tribunal with specific notice and hearing procedures.

title: Immediate Suspension Authority
content: The registrar can immediately suspend registrations in cases of public interest, with appeal rights and automatic expiration of temporary suspensions if hearings are requested within specified timeframes.

title: Inspector and Investigator Appointment
content: The registrar appoints inspectors for compliance monitoring and investigators for formal inquiries. Both receive certificates of appointment and have defined powers and duties under TRESA.

title: Search Warrant and Investigation Powers
content: Investigators can obtain search warrants for premises and electronic devices, conduct searches with expert assistance, and seize relevant documents and evidence for regulatory investigations.

title: Exigent Circumstances Search Authority
content: Investigators can conduct warrantless searches if warrant conditions exist but circumstances prevent obtaining judicial authorization, with subsequent reporting requirements to judicial authorities.

title: Evidence Seizure and Return Procedures
content: Seized materials must be properly documented, stored securely, and returned to owners within reasonable timeframes unless required for ongoing investigations or legal proceedings.

title: Plain View Seizure Authority
content: Investigators can seize evidence discovered in plain view during lawful inspections or searches, even if not specifically mentioned in original warrants or inspection authorizations.

title: Asset Freeze and Preservation Orders
content: The director can order preservation of registrant assets during investigations, requiring financial institutions and other holders to retain funds and prevent unauthorized asset transfers.

title: Trust Fund Administration and Unclaimed Property
content: Unclaimed trust funds must be transferred to regulatory authorities after prescribed periods, with procedures for claiming funds and administrative authority responsibilities for fund management.

title: Interest Allocation and Administrative Costs
content: Interest earned on trust funds can be allocated to administrative costs, with specific rules for capital preservation and cost recovery from trust fund earnings.

title: Director and Deputy Director Authority
content: The director oversees regulatory operations with authority to appoint deputies, delegate functions, and ensure consistent administration of TRESA across all regulatory activities.

title: Registrar and Deputy Registrar Functions
content: The registrar manages registration processes, conducts investigations, and oversees compliance, with deputy registrars providing continuity and backup administrative functions.

title: Administrative Authority Designation
content: The administrative authority designated under the Safety and Consumer Statutes Administration Act, 1996 provides administrative support and oversight for TRESA implementation and enforcement.

title: Ministerial Oversight and Policy Direction
content: The Minister of Consumer and Business Services provides policy direction, approves regulations, establishes fees, and ensures TRESA aligns with broader consumer protection objectives.

title: Regulatory Framework and Rule-Making
content: The Lieutenant Governor in Council can make regulations prescribing technical details, procedural requirements, and specific standards for TRESA implementation and administration.

title: Transitional and Implementation Provisions
content: TRESA includes specific provisions for transitioning from previous legislation, grandfathering existing registrations, and ensuring continuity during regulatory implementation phases.

title: Repeal and Citation Provisions
content: TRESA repeals previous legislation while preserving citation references and ensuring legal continuity for existing agreements, registrations, and regulatory actions.
